key_points: Facebook is discontinuing its facial recognition system, affecting 1 billion users.
The decision follows legal and regulatory scrutiny, including a $5 billion FTC fine and a $650 million class-action lawsuit in Illinois.
About a third of Facebook users have facial recognition features enabled.
Digital rights advocates applaud the move but argue all facial recognition technology should be banned due to privacy and accuracy concerns.
Facebook's database of identified photos is one of the largest in the world, requiring users to manually tag photos going forward.
Facebook's parent company, Meta, is pivoting towards a new public image amidst these changes.
Several U.S. cities and states have passed laws limiting facial recognition software use.
Tech companies like IBM and Amazon have also distanced themselves from facial recognition.
Criticism extends to other companies and governments using facial recognition technology.
Apple's Face ID includes safeguards to prevent misuse, but users concerned about privacy can opt for a PIN instead.
spokespersons: Caitlin Seeley George (Campaign Director, Fight for the Future)
